RESOLVED_ENTITIES.The United States Court of Appeals for t: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.The United States of America Constitutio: the United States of America Constitution
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Pe: The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.AEDPA: The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Pub. L. No. 104-132: The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya: defendant whose punishment is being determined, with counsel Adrian Almaguer raising objections to the base offense level calculated in the Presentence Report
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Nancy F. Atlas: judge who must apply the correct version of the sentencing guidelines and overruled defense counsel's objection regarding the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual edition, denying a certificate of appealability
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America: Plaintiff in the case, opposing Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's motion for relief
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.foreign nationals: persons held for ransom and against their will
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Federal Grand Jury: grand jury that may deny a certificate of appealability, sua sponte, without requiring further briefing or argument
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Presentence Report: report prepared for determining punishment under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual, with objections raised by Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's counsel
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.PSR: abbreviation for Presentence Report, used in determining sentence based on the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Guidelines Manu: manual used to determine sentences, with versions applicable at different times, including the 2003 and 2004 editions
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.The United States Court of Appeals for t: court that established the principle for applying sentencing guidelines, relevant to Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States Supreme Court: highest court in the United States, which could have been appealed to regarding the application of the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Adrian Almaguer: Attorney for Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya, who raised objections to the base offense level calculated in the Presentence Report and acknowledged using an incorrect version of the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America Constitutio: Document outlining the fundamental laws and principles of the United States, including prohibitions on ex post facto laws, relevant to the application of sentencing guidelines
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.ex post facto Law: law that prohibits applying a more onerous penalty than was in effect at the time of the offense, considered in the context of Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's punishment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States Congress: Legislative body of the United States, prohibited from enacting ex post facto laws, and responsible for amendments to the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal alien smuggling venture: smuggling operation involving illegal aliens, subject to the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's motion: motion filed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, requiring a certificate of appealability to proceed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Pe: federal law governing appeals in certain cases, including those related to illegal alien smuggling ventures
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.certificate of appealability: document required for an appeal to proceed, which will not be issued unless the petitioner makes a substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right
